Good article on everyday decisions programmers face, also I'd say it's pretty easy to spot the "dark patterns" mentioned there. (ctd) https://t.co/f75Gporjkc
Some things are really obviously aimed to do harm. E.g. developing guiding software for a weapon. But other not so:
Software is in most case just a tool. If it is used for bad purpose, depends on the user / the company that employs it for a specific use.
Take databases. They can be use to catalog a lot of things, e.g. virus infections, and this can be use to save lives.
The same database can be used to catalog muslims to deport them.
For us developers it is therefore important to understand the complete context of our work, not just the immediate user story at hand.
But to foresee and prevent every negative use of software is impossible.
@TAKEaCiCi @Nis5 Actually, one of the rare examples where #fintech is used for something for the benefit of humans, not as an investment.

@c089 tough, what can help in my experience are techniques from the non-violent communication. Try to understand the different layers of

@c089 what is communicated, what the situation of the other person might be.
If unsure, I try to politely pry for more details.
@c089 "I don't understand ..." / "Can you make a concrete example."
@c089 also, don't answer on impulse (also non-violent), let it simmer for a while if potentially controversial.

Yesterday I talked to an Austrian who was thinking about skipping bachelor and instead taking a job at a company. 
I gave him this advice:
The older you get, the harder it will be to get back to University, because the life style change is not easy. It's a downgrade.
I only studied late, because I got a scholarship which I didn't have to pay back and my wife was working full time.
But more important: we have the privilege of free education, you owe it to our society that makes this possible to take this chance.
Don't give up a chance to change your whole life for some short-lived opportunity. NO company can guarantee that they exist in 5 yrs.
A degree will influence how you appeal to organizations. Even if you have a lot of experience, candidates with degrees will come first.
And, it's super fun. You'll learn so much about your craft, yourself, that you'll never learn working for companies.
It's also the nucleus for a great network of people, your future friends, cofounders and colleagues.
